Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: High Efficiency Tandem Perovskite/CIS Solar Cell

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Non-technical:
Solar photovoltaic (PV) energy conversion is an important technology for generating low-cost electricity to replace coal-generated power. It is also very important for providing electricity to half of the people in the world who currently lack grid-connected power. For economical generation of PV power, efficiency of solar cells is a very important consideration, since area-related costs such as encapsulation, wiring and structure decrease proportionately as the efficiency of the cell increases. A very recent development in this field has been the discovery that a new thin film material, hybrid organic-inorganic metal halide based perovskites, can be used to generate PV power with a conversion efficiency of ~20%. This new material has a larger bandgap than commonly used thin film materials such as copper-indium-gallium selenide (CIGS), and therefore, can be used as a higher bandgap first cell in a monolithic tandem solar cell arrangement with CIGS. Calculations predict that such a series-connected tandem cell structures can increase the efficiency of thin film CIGS solar cells to 30% from the current value of 20%, a 50% increase. This proposal is aimed towards fundamental material and device research to achieve such high efficiency tandem cell structures. It is hoped that such a structure will lead to further developments which result in a significant decrease in the cost of solar-electric power. A graduate student will participate in this project and new teaching materials will be incorporated into courses dealing with solar energy conversion.

Technical:

The proposal is focused on designing and fabricating a monolithic tandem cell structure with a high gap perovskite cell deposited on top of a high efficiency CIGS cell. The two cells are connected using novel tunnel junctions. Several new materials, processes and device structures need to be developed for the concept to work. Among these are:
-A perovskite material with a bandgap in the 1.7-1.8 eV range as opposed to the current 1.57 eV material. The higher bandgap is needed to make efficient tandem cells with a CIGS bottom cell. We will develop efficient Pb(I-Br) perovskites to increase the bandgap.
-A perovskite material which is physically stable at higher temperatures so that transparent contacts can be deposited on the device to allow light to be incident form the top of the cell. We will use novel organic precursors such as formamidinium iodide and urea hydroiodide to achieve thermally stable perovskites.
-A new vacuum process for depositing perovskites at higher temperatures which avoids the instability of the solution growth process.
-The use of inorganic heterojunction layers for electron and hole extraction , thus avoiding unstable organic heterojunction layers.
-ITO/ZnO tunnel junctions to connect the two cells.
-Innovative CIGS cells in1.1 to1.15 eV range with high efficiency achieved by using bandgap grading strategies along with larger grain growth and deliberate Na or K doping.
The project includes comprehensive material and device analysis tasks so as to understand the physics of the device.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This project was focused on developing high efficiency perovskite solar cells with a bandgap appropriate for making tandem cells with Si.

Intellectual merit:

The following scientific discoveries were made during  the course of this project:

  • Development of a thermally stable inorganic perovskite material and solar cell. By eliminating organic cation, and replacing it with an inorganic cation (Cs), we discovered that the perovskite material did not degrade even at 300 ℃, in contrast to hybrid organic perovskites which degrade in the range of 85-120 ℃. This was major discovery because in operation, the perovskite cells will be deployed in climates which reach 50-55 ℃ ambient temperatures, with cell temperatures approaching ~95-100 ℃. The new inorganic material can easily withstand such temperatures, whereas the hybrid materials cannot. The bandgaps of the material were about 1.85 eV, close enough to eh optimum 1.75 eV bandgap for matching with Si.
  • A new process based on intercalation of vacuum deposited individual layers was developed to fabricate the perovskite material. The process was highly reproducible.
  • The degradation of the perovskite devices is dependent on both the heterojunction interfaces as well as on the bulk material. Devices with inorganic heterojunctions degrade much less than devices with organic heterojunctions.
  • Ions generated by light within the perovskite material crossed over to the metal contact and degraded it. An interlayer of CdS between the perovskite and the back contact prevented such ion migration and preserved the ohmic contact.
  • A new experimental technique to study time dependence of degradation under varying intensities of light was developed to study the influence of interfaces. It was found that the interface induced degradation occurred over a much shorter time scale than the bulk-ion-induced degradation.

Broader impact:

  • Three Ph.D. students and one M.S. student were graduated based in part on support from this project. One of the students was a female student.One undergraduate student also participated in the research.
  • The PI gave 15 invited talks in the U.S. or abroad on the research.7 of the talks were IEEE-EDS Distinguished lectures or talks at mini-colloquiums organized by IEEE. He also taught a 3 hour workshop on perovskite solar cells at IIT-Bombay, India.
  • 8 papers were published in archival journals or in refereed proceedings of IEEE conferences. All the papers had students as co-authors.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2020
Modified by: Vikram L Dalal

By eliminating organic cation, and replacing it with an inorganic cation (Cs), we discovered that the perovskite material did not degrade even at 300 ℃, in contrast to hybrid organic perovskites which degrade in the range of 85-120 ℃. The new inorganic material can easily withstand such temperatures, whereas the hybrid materials cannot. The bandgaps of the material were about 1.85 eV, close enough to eh optimum 1.75 eV bandgap for matching with Si. A new process based on intercalation of vacuum deposited individual layers was developed to fabricate the perovskite material. The process was highly reproducible. The degradation of the perovskite devices is dependent on both the heterojunction interfaces as well as on the bulk material. Devices with inorganic heterojunctions degrade much less than devices with organic heterojunctions. Ions generated by light within the perovskite material crossed over to the metal contact and degraded it.
